Since we're casting this result later maybe it'd be good to return a more specific type here and add an `is` check?

nitty nit nit: we really prefer it when the code is vertically aligned cleanly, as in:
```dart
    return base.hashCode
￼         ^ assetEntry.hashCode
         ^ relativePath.hashCode
         ^ source.hashCode;
￼```
Maybe add a small comment on the difference between these two: Why do we need to resolve the first on (above), but not this one?

comments.body: Magic number 9. Maybe `'packages/'.length`? Or declare a `const String packagesPrefix = 'packages/';` and use `packagesPrefix.length`.
Any good reason we are printing an error message using `printStatus`?

If `asset` is `packages/vacation/sunset.jpg`, we get
```
relativeAsset == 'sunset.jpg'
packageKey == 'vacation'
```
That seems reasonable. But if `asset` is `packages/vacation_sunset.jpg`, we get
```
relativeAsset == 'packages/vacation_sunset.jpg'
packageKey == 'vacation_sunset.jpg'
```
That appears backwards to me?
Formatting. Hurts. My. Eyes.

Pubspec field extraction logic appears mixed with our specific use of gathering font info. I suspect this is not the only place in our code base where knowledge of the pubspec file organization is implicitly present. I suggest we introduce a `Pubspec` class to explicitly represent this knowledge, and which has high-level getters for the contents we care about. Like 

```dart
class Pubspec {
  ...
  bool get usesMaterialDesign => ...
  List<Map<String, dynamic>> get fonts => ...
}
```
This way, we separate code that knows about how to extract info from pubspec from code that knows about what to do with that info.
Agree. I will do this in another PR.
This method no longer returns `null` if the fonts map is empty. Does that work with all callers?
I believe so.
Cf. earlier comment. This method might benefit from an explicit `FontDescriptor` class. Hopefully we wouldn't then have to throw around so many variables of type `Map<String, dynamic>` in one place.

comments.body: [Avoid curly braces around single-line blocks](https://github.com/flutter/flutter/wiki/Style-guide-for-Flutter-repo#avoid-using-braces-for-one-line-long-control-structure-statements).

Alas, it looks like the `json-schema` dart package doesn't support the `$comment` keyword, so we can't add comments to the schema to document the syntax of assets in the manifest there.

However, there is https://flutter.io/assets-and-images/ -- can you also send a PR to update the documentation on the website that'll go in tandem with this?

Done 2 weeks ago: https://github.com/flutter/website/pull/992.
Not sure how to coordinate the merge, would you like me to remind you when this merge lands on beta so you can merge the `flutter/website`?
Yeah, that'd be great.  thanks!
